title: Nominal Clauses
description: Слушайте именные придаточные в роли подлежащего и дополнения.

tasks.audioText: The committee spent hours in deliberation. What ultimately mattered was whether the proposal aligned with the company's long-term vision.
tasks.transcript: What ultimately mattered was whether the proposal aligned with the company's long-term vision.

options.text: The key question was the proposal's compatibility with the company's future direction.
The committee immediately approved the proposal.
Nobody cared about the long-term vision.
The proposal was rejected due to budget constraints.

tasks.explanation: 'What ultimately mattered' is a nominal clause acting as the subject. The sentence focuses on alignment with the company's vision as the critical factor.

tasks.audioText: The scientist presented her findings at the symposium. Whether the hypothesis holds true depends on the results of further clinical trials.
tasks.transcript: Whether the hypothesis holds true depends on the results of further clinical trials.

options.text: The hypothesis has already been confirmed.
The validity of the hypothesis is contingent upon additional experimental evidence.
No further testing is needed.
The clinical trials have been cancelled.

tasks.explanation: 'Whether the hypothesis holds true' is a nominal clause as subject. The sentence states that confirmation requires more clinical data.

tasks.audioText: The journalist investigated the corruption scandal for months. The fact that several officials had resigned only strengthened her suspicions.
tasks.transcript: The fact that several officials had resigned only strengthened her suspicions.

options.text: The officials' resignations made the journalist less suspicious.
The journalist stopped her investigation after the resignations.
Multiple officials stepping down actually reinforced the journalist's doubts.
No officials had resigned during the investigation.

tasks.explanation: 'The fact that several officials had resigned' is a nominal clause as subject. Their departures confirmed rather than dispelled her concerns.

tasks.audioText: The hiring manager reviewed dozens of applications. Whoever demonstrates the strongest analytical skills will be offered the position.
tasks.transcript: Whoever demonstrates the strongest analytical skills will be offered the position.

options.text: The position has already been filled.
The job will go to the candidate with the best analytical abilities.
All applicants will be offered the position.
Analytical skills are not important for this role.

tasks.explanation: 'Whoever demonstrates the strongest analytical skills' is a nominal clause as subject using the free relative pronoun 'whoever'.

tasks.audioText: The diplomat returned from the negotiations visibly frustrated. He could not accept that the treaty had been altered without prior consultation.
tasks.transcript: He could not accept that the treaty had been altered without prior consultation.

options.text: He was fine with the changes made to the treaty.
The treaty was never modified.
He found it unacceptable that the agreement was changed without discussing it first.
He was the one who changed the treaty.

tasks.explanation: 'That the treaty had been altered without prior consultation' is a nominal clause as object of 'accept'. He rejected the unauthorized changes.

tasks.audioText: The professor addressed the doctoral students at orientation. How you approach your research methodology will define the quality of your dissertation.
tasks.transcript: How you approach your research methodology will define the quality of your dissertation.

options.text: Your research methods are irrelevant to dissertation quality.
The way you handle your research methods will determine how good your thesis is.
All dissertations receive the same quality grade.
The professor will choose each student's research methodology.

tasks.explanation: 'How you approach your research methodology' is a nominal wh-clause functioning as the subject. The method dictates the outcome.

tasks.audioText: The CEO delivered her annual address. She emphasized that innovation without ethical consideration would ultimately undermine the brand.
tasks.transcript: She emphasized that innovation without ethical consideration would ultimately undermine the brand.

options.text: She believed ethics were irrelevant to innovation.
She stressed that pursuing innovation without ethics could damage the company's reputation.
The brand was already damaged beyond repair.
She announced the company would stop innovating.

tasks.explanation: 'That innovation without ethical consideration would ultimately undermine the brand' is a that-clause as object of 'emphasized'.

tasks.audioText: The architect presented the urban development plan. Where the new cultural centre is built will significantly affect local property values.
tasks.transcript: Where the new cultural centre is built will significantly affect local property values.

options.text: Property values are unaffected by the location of new buildings.
The cultural centre has already been completed.
The location chosen for the cultural centre will have a major impact on nearby property prices.
Local residents oppose all new construction.

tasks.explanation: 'Where the new cultural centre is built' is a nominal wh-clause as subject. The location will meaningfully influence property prices.

tasks.audioText: The therapist listened carefully to her patient's concerns. What troubled him most was that his family seemed unwilling to acknowledge the problem.
tasks.transcript: What troubled him most was that his family seemed unwilling to acknowledge the problem.

options.text: His greatest distress came from his family's apparent refusal to recognize the issue.
His family was very supportive during his therapy.
He was not troubled by anything in particular.
The therapist was the one who was troubled.

tasks.explanation: This sentence has two nominal clauses: 'What troubled him most' as subject and 'that his family seemed unwilling...' as complement. The family's denial was his main concern.

tasks.audioText: The defence attorney presented closing arguments. Whether the jury believes the testimony of the sole witness remains to be seen.
tasks.transcript: Whether the jury believes the testimony of the sole witness remains to be seen.

options.text: The jury has already reached a verdict.
There were multiple witnesses in the case.
It is still uncertain if the jury will find the only witness credible.
The witness refused to testify in court.

tasks.explanation: 'Whether the jury believes the testimony' is a nominal clause as subject. The outcome of the jury's assessment is still unknown.

tasks.audioText: The literary critic published a controversial review. That the novel was largely autobiographical seemed evident to anyone familiar with the author's life.
tasks.transcript: That the novel was largely autobiographical seemed evident to anyone familiar with the author's life.

options.text: The novel had nothing to do with the author's real life.
It was obvious that the book was mostly based on the author's own experiences.
Nobody realized the novel was autobiographical.
The critic did not read the novel before reviewing it.

tasks.explanation: 'That the novel was largely autobiographical' is a that-clause functioning as subject. The autobiographical nature was clear to informed readers.

tasks.audioText: The investors gathered for the quarterly briefing. The question of whether the startup could sustain its growth rate dominated the discussion.
tasks.transcript: The question of whether the startup could sustain its growth rate dominated the discussion.

options.text: Investors were confident the startup would maintain its growth.
The startup's ability to keep growing was the main topic of conversation.
The investors discussed unrelated matters.
The startup had already gone bankrupt.

tasks.explanation: 'Whether the startup could sustain its growth rate' is a nominal clause within a noun phrase. The sustainability of growth was the central concern.

tasks.audioText: The school principal addressed parents at the open evening. She assured them that the new curriculum would better prepare students for higher education.
tasks.transcript: She assured them that the new curriculum would better prepare students for higher education.

options.text: She warned parents that the curriculum changes would be harmful.
She promised that the updated programme would improve students' readiness for university.
The curriculum would remain exactly the same.
Parents demanded that the old curriculum be restored.

tasks.explanation: 'That the new curriculum would better prepare students' is a that-clause as object of 'assured'. She gave parents confidence about the change.

tasks.audioText: The climate conference concluded with a joint statement. What the delegates agreed upon was that immediate action on carbon emissions is non-negotiable.
tasks.transcript: What the delegates agreed upon was that immediate action on carbon emissions is non-negotiable.

options.text: The delegates could not reach any agreement.
Carbon emissions were not discussed at the conference.
The delegates decided to postpone action on emissions.
The delegates reached consensus that urgent emission reductions are absolutely necessary.

tasks.explanation: Two nominal clauses: 'What the delegates agreed upon' (subject) and 'that immediate action... is non-negotiable' (complement). The consensus was on the urgency of action.

tasks.audioText: The detective reviewed the surveillance footage meticulously. Why the suspect had returned to the crime scene puzzled the entire investigative team.
tasks.transcript: Why the suspect had returned to the crime scene puzzled the entire investigative team.

options.text: The team understood exactly why the suspect came back.
The suspect's reason for revisiting the scene of the crime confused all the investigators.
The suspect never returned to the crime scene.
The detective solved the case immediately.

tasks.explanation: 'Why the suspect had returned to the crime scene' is a nominal wh-clause as subject. The motive for returning baffled the investigators.
